text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani newspapers on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-Police rounded up 19 activists of a Sunni Moslem militant organisation in Lahore, provincial capital of Punjab.

- More than 40 people, including policemen, were injured and around 200 arrested when farmers protesting against the imposition of agriculture tax clashed with police in Sargodha town in central Punjab.
- The Supreme Court of Pakistan will start inquiry into ethnic killings in Karachi from Saturday.

- The Chief of Air Staff Mohammad Abbas Khattak removed two senior officers of the Pakistan Air Force Academy at Risalpur from their posts and ordered a court martial of senior cadets allegedly involved in the death of two aviation cadets by ragging.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will pay an official visit to Malaysia between July 31 and August 3 to enhance bilateral relations.
- A mission of the U.S.-based credit rating agency Moody's Investors Service Inc. will visit Pakistan in October to assess Pakistan's sovereign risk, a brokerage house said.
- Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz said that after the agreement with the International Monetary Fund for a soft loan, the crisis of debt servicing is over for at least one year.
- The state-run Karachi Port Trust is actively considering a downward revision of tariff for container ships to make the port charges comparable with Port Qasim, Karachi's second port.
